question_text: Major depressive disorder requires symptoms to persist for a minimum duration before a clinical diagnosis can be made. What is this minimum duration according to standard diagnostic criteria?
correct_answer: At least two weeks of persistent depressed mood or loss of interest in nearly all activities
distractors: At least one month of continuous sadness accompanied by significant weight change
At least six months of low mood with at least three episodes of crying per week
At least three days of inability to get out of bed combined with social withdrawal

question_text: Anxiety involves both psychological and physical responses to perceived threats. Which of the following best describes the core feature that distinguishes clinical anxiety from ordinary worry?
correct_answer: Persistent and excessive worry that disrupts normal functioning even when no immediate threat is present
distractors: Brief episodes of nervousness that occur only in genuinely dangerous situations
A complete inability to experience any positive emotions during stressful periods
Occasional physical tension that resolves immediately once the stressful event ends

question_text: Psychotherapy encompasses a range of methods used by mental health professionals. What is the common element shared across all forms of psychotherapy?
correct_answer: Direct personal contact between therapist and patient, typically through structured conversation
distractors: Prescription of medication to correct chemical imbalances underlying mental health conditions
Use of standardized diagnostic imaging such as brain scans to guide treatment decisions
Assignment of daily written homework exercises that the patient completes independently

question_text: The World Health Organization and the American Psychiatric Association each publish a major classification system for mental disorders. What are these two widely used systems?
correct_answer: The International Classification of Diseases (ICD) and the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM)
distractors: The Global Burden of Disease Index (GBDI) and the Psychiatric Rating Scale Manual (PRSM)
The World Mental Health Survey (WMHS) and the Clinical Assessment of Functioning (CAF)
The International Behavioral Codex (IBC) and the American Neuropsychiatric Registry (ANR)

question_text: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is organized around distinct symptom clusters in the DSM-5. Which of the following correctly identifies the four main symptom clusters?
correct_answer: Intrusion symptoms, avoidance, negative changes in cognition and mood, and changes in arousal and reactivity
distractors: Hallucinations, social withdrawal, loss of motor function, and chronic fatigue
Obsessive thoughts, compulsive rituals, depersonalization, and appetite disturbance
Grandiosity, impulsivity, emotional numbness, and dissociative identity shifts

question_text: Phobias are among the most common anxiety disorders. What is the defining characteristic that distinguishes a phobia from normal fear?
correct_answer: An intense, irrational fear that is disproportionate to the actual danger posed by the object or situation
distractors: A fear response that occurs only in childhood and naturally disappears by adulthood
A realistic assessment of danger that leads to appropriate and proportional avoidance behavior
A sudden fear that appears without any identifiable trigger or environmental stimulus

question_text: The physiological stress response involves activation of the body's major regulatory systems. Walter Cannon first described this acute stress response in 1915 using what well-known term?
correct_answer: The fight-or-flight response, involving sympathetic nervous system activation to prepare the body for action
distractors: The general adaptation syndrome, a three-stage process of alarm, resistance, and exhaustion
The relaxation response, a parasympathetic mechanism that counteracts physical tension
The tend-and-befriend response, a social bonding reaction triggered by the release of oxytocin

question_text: Psychological trauma can result in both short-term and long-term reactions. Which of the following correctly pairs common short-term and long-term responses to a traumatic event?
correct_answer: Short-term: psychological shock and denial; long-term: flashbacks, panic attacks, and possible development of PTSD
distractors: Short-term: permanent memory loss of the event; long-term: gradual recovery of all lost memories
Short-term: immediate onset of hallucinations; long-term: development of intellectual disability
Short-term: complete emotional numbness for several years; long-term: spontaneous full recovery without treatment

question_text: Addiction is now understood as a neuropsychological disorder. What is the core characteristic that defines addiction according to current clinical understanding?
correct_answer: A persistent and intense urge to use a substance or engage in a behavior despite substantial harm and negative consequences
distractors: A deliberate choice to continue using a substance purely for recreational enjoyment without any compulsion
A temporary physical dependence on a substance that resolves completely once the substance is discontinued
A moral failing characterized by lack of willpower that affects only individuals with low intelligence

question_text: Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is classified as a neurodevelopmental condition. What are the two core symptom domains used to diagnose ASD in the DSM-5?
correct_answer: Differences in social communication and interaction, and restricted or repetitive patterns of behavior and interests
distractors: Deficits in reading comprehension and mathematics, and an inability to form any long-term memories
Persistent auditory hallucinations and visual disturbances, and severe impairment of motor coordination
Chronic mood instability and emotional outbursts, and progressive loss of previously acquired language skills
